addressleaf.section:
To
e right honorable my very singular good Lord,
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasuer of England.

24 Julij
1591
. M
r
Bodeleie to my L.
With l
res
intercepted of
Le Vasseur.

page.lettertext:
fol.254r
May it please yo
r
good L. there were of o
r
souldiers that came this morning to
e
Count,
w
t
certaine letters of
e Enemie, w
ch
they had
intercepted: among w
ch
there were two of
Vasseur a secretary of their state, and of
great a utoritie among them. I have sent
yo
r
L.
e transcript of them bothe, supposing
it needefull,
at
e teno
r
of
e one declaring
expressely,
at there is order out of
Spaine
for
e
Duke
to goe for
France,
and likewise of
e other contening
e specialties of
e Enemies
forces expected out of
Germany,
should be spee-
dely notified to her
Ma
tie
.
For we did never
make account of more then a 1500 horse,
and some fewe enseignes of foote,
at they had
levied in those quarters. Whether
e
Veado
r
, to whome letter is addressed, be
at
Brussels
or
Andwerp,
we can not certainly
learne. For it was omitted in
e indorsment
of
e letter. I signified in my last,
e
23 of this moneth, at
e Duke was marched from
Niuemeghen
towardes
e Maese, w
t
intention, as
nowe it is certified, to pitche his campe at
Maestricht.
Howbeit we knowe it not otherwise
then by these intercepted: nor we are not
yet assured, if he leave any garrison in
Nieumeghen. Being otherwise destitute
of a present messenger, I requested
M
r
Allen
e bearer heerof, to carie these letters
of purpose: w
ch
I hope will stand w
t
yo
r
L. good liking, and I am certaine he will
use all possible diligence.
And so I take
my humble leave. From Arnham. July 24
1591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden. Tho. Bodley
